pageContext.claim: “In 2018 alone...there was a 122% increase in fentanyl being smuggled between ports of entry.”
pageContext.analysis: Trump is quoting Sean Hannity of Fox News and the source of this statistic in unclear. However, historical data shows that the amounts of drugs smuggled in between the ports of entry is on the decrease. The total number of marijuana seized in 2017, the last full year of data available, is almost a third of what it was in in 2012. Meanwhile, there has been a notable increase in the smuggling of hard drugs at ports of entry, according to Customs and Border Protection figures. Through Aug. 31, 2018, four times more fentanyl was seized at ports of entry rather than between such ports.
